questions.text: A 64-year-old man is admitted to the psychiatric unit after an unsuccessful suicide attempt. Following admission, he attempts to cut his wrists three times in the next 24 hours and refuses to eat or drink anything. He is scheduled to have electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) because he is so severely depressed that an antidepressant is deemed too slow acting. Which of the following side effects should the patient be informed of is most common after ECT?

options.label: A
options.text: Headache

options.label: B
options.text: Palpitations

options.label: C
options.text: Interictal confusion

options.label: D
options.text: Worsening of the suicidal ideation

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Headache The most common complaints after ECT include headaches, nausea, and muscle soreness. Memory impairment (both retrograde and anterograde) does occur but less frequently.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: B . Cardiovascular changes do occur, but they are rare and happen mostly in the immediate postictal period or during the seizure Option: C . Interictal confusion is quite uncommon after ECT Option: D. ECT is beneficial in reducing suicidal ideation. Suicidal ideation is an indication of ECT

questions.text: A 45-year-old female diagnosed with major depressive disorder presented to the emergency room with failed suicidal attempt. She further expresses her desire to end her life. The psychiatrist evaluates her for electroconvulsive therapy (ECT). Which of the following statements regarding ECT is false?

options.label: A
options.text: ECT should be used in cases of psychotic depression only.

options.label: B
options.text: Bilateral ECT is somewhat more effective than unilateral ECT.

options.label: C
options.text: Retrograde memory impairment is a common side effect.

options.label: D
options.text: 6 to 12 treatments are usually needed for symptomatic remission in this case.

questions.correct_answer: A. ECT should be used in cases of psychotic depression only.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

ECT should be used in cases of psychotic depression only. Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) is effective in psychotic and nonpsychotic forms of depression.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: B . Bilateral ECT is somewhat more effective than unilateral therapy, but bilateral ECT also appears to have more cognitive side effects, such as retrograde memory loss. Option: C . Retrograde memory impairment is a common side effect of ECT. Option: D . Usually, 6 to 12 ECT treatments are required to achieve symptomatic remission in patients with MDD.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man, accompanied by his wife, presents to a psychiatrist. The man has a 5-year history of depression and has tried several antidepressant medications without satisfaction. The psychiatrist evaluates the patient for electroconvulsive therapy (ECT). Which of the following is TRUE regarding ECT?

options.label: A
options.text: Patients of age 84 years should not receive ECT.

options.label: B
options.text: A primigravida in 2nd month of pregnancy should not receive ECT.

options.label: C
options.text: Pt. of GTCS who had a recent seizure episode 6 days back, while on medication is a contraindication for ECT.

options.label: D
options.text: There are no absolute contraindications for ECT.

questions.correct_answer: D. There are no absolute contraindications for ECT.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

There are no absolute contraindications for ECT. Pregnancy is a relative contraindication.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Elderly is not an absolute or relative contraindication to ECT. Option: B. ECT may be the most appropriate treatment for a variety of disorders in a first-trimester pregnant patient, for whom certain medications pose a teratogenic risk to the fetus. Option: C . Patients with a seizure disorder on anticonvulsants can safely be treated with ECT.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about deep brain stimulation?

options.label: A
options.text: Three tiny neurostimulators were placed under the skin of the clavicle.

options.label: B
options.text: Done under CT guidance

options.label: C
options.text: Reduces symptoms associated with movement disorders

options.label: D
options.text: Swimming skills remain intact after the procedure.

questions.correct_answer: C. Reduces symptoms associated with movement disorders
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Reduces symptoms associated with movement disorders Deep brain stimulation can cure certain movement disorders like Parkinson’s disease which are resistant to medicines.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: A & B . It is an invasive procedure performed using MRI- guided stereotactic technologies in which electrodes are implanted in the brain & are connected via a subcutaneous wire to a maximum of two neurostimulators which are placed under the skin of the clavicle. Option: D . Impaired swimming skills surfaced as an unexpected risk of the procedures; several Parkinson's Disease patients lost their ability to swim after receiving deep brain stimulation.

questions.text: Which of the following is an advantage of Transcranial magnetic stimulation over ECT?

options.label: A
options.text: It is more effective than ECT

options.label: B
options.text: Shorter treatment course

options.label: C
options.text: It induces seizures of shorter duration

options.label: D
options.text: It allows for focal stimulation of the cerebral cortex

questions.correct_answer: D. It allows for focal stimulation of the cerebral cortex
questions.explanation:
Solution:

It allows for focal stimulation of the cerebral cortex Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) is a brain stimulation method that allows for focal stimulation of the cerebral cortex .

Highyeild:

TMS works by inducing eddy currents in the brain cortex due to the application of rapidly changing magnetic fields . These currents bring about neuronal stimulation . This can be useful for the treatment of resistant depression . The advantage of TMS over ECT is that TMS allows for focal stimulation of brain areas.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: A . Studies have shown TMS to be less effective than ECT. Option: B. TMS is not a shorter treatment course. Option: C . It does not induce seizures, but unintended seizure is a known risk of this procedure.
